Recall from \cite{H2} that the minus partial order $\overset{-}\leq$ in a ring $R$ is defined as follows:
\vskip 2mm

$a\overset{-}\leq b$ if and only if $a^{-}a = a^{-}b$ and $aa^{-} = ba^{-}$ for some $a^- \in a\{1\}$.
\vskip 2mm

\noindent
The following characterization of the minus partial order will be used in the proof of Theorem \ref{core-minus-regular},
which plays an important role in the sequel.

\begin{lem} \emph{\cite{LPT}} \label{minus-regular}
If both $a$ and $b$ have inner inverses in a ring $R$
then the following conditions are equivalent :\\
$(1)$ $a\overset{-}\leq b$;\\
$(2)$ $a=bb^{-}a=ab^{-}b=ab^{-}a$ for some $b^{-}\in b\{1\}$;\\
$(3)$ $a=bb^{-}a=ab^{-}b=ab^{-}a$ for all $b^{-}\in b\{1\}$.
\end{lem}

\begin{thm} \label{core-minus-regular}
Let $a,~b \in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ with $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$.
Then the following equalities hold:\\
$(1)$ $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$; \\
$(2)$ $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$;\\
$(3)$ $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b=b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$; \\
$(4)$ $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$; \\
$(5)$ $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
      = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$; \\
$(6)$ $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
      = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
      = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
\end{thm}
\begin{proof}
Note that $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$ implies $a\overset{-}\leq b$.
On the other hand, $b \in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ guarantees
$b \in R^{\#}$ by \cite[Theorem 2.11 and 2.14]{RDD}.
So we have $a = bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a = bb^{\#}a$ by Lemma \ref{minus-regular}.

(1) Since $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                                              = $(bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a)a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    and $(aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^*$ = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ by Lemma \ref{five-equations-yy},
    it follows that
      $bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $(bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^{*}$
    = $(aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^*(bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^*$
    = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
    But $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$ = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$ by hypothesis.
    Hence
      $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
    Combining these facts we get
      $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

(2) First, we have
      $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    by (1).
    Note that $b = b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^2$ by Lemma \ref{five-equations-yy}.
    Hence
      $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}(b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^2)a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
    Since $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$ = $b^\#$ (see \cite[Theorem 2.19(ii)]{RDD}),
    it follows that
      $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}(b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^2)a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $(b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b)(ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})$
    = $b^\#ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$,
    where $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    by Lemma \ref{five-equations-yy}.
    Thus
      $b^\#ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $b^\#b(aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})$
    = $(bb^\#a)a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
    To sum up, we have
      $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}(b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^2)a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $b^\#ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

(3) Since $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    and $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$ = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$ by hypothesis,
    it follows that
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
    $\overset{(2)}{=\!\!=}$
    $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
    $\overset{(1)}{=\!\!=}$
    $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
    = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
    = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$
    = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$.

(4) $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    $\overset{(1)}{=\!\!=}$
    $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    $\overset{(2)}{=\!\!=}$
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

(5) $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    $\overset{(1)}{=\!\!=}$
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    $\overset{(3)}{=\!\!=}$
    $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    $\overset{(2)}{=\!\!=}$
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

(6) $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    $\overset{(3)}{=\!\!=}$
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    $\overset{(1)}{=\!\!=}$
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    $\overset{(5)}{=\!\!=}$
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
\end{proof}


\begin{rem}\label{slip1}
\emph{In \cite[Theorem $2.4$]{M2}, it is claimed that the following are equivalent for two complex matrices $A,B$ of index $1$ with the same order:\\
$(1)$ $A^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}BA^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=A^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$;\\
$(2)$ $A^{\dagger}BA^\#=A^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}.$}

\emph{While the implication $(2)\Rightarrow(1)$ is always valid,
the converse is not true in genral. In fact,
let
$A=B=\left(\begin{matrix}
              1 & 1 \\
              0 & 0
       \end{matrix}
       \right)\in \mathrm{M}_{2}(\mathbb{C})$\normalsize,
then
$A^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}BA^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
= $A^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}AA^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ = $A^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
However, $A^{\dagger}BA^\#\neq A^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}.$
We note that $(1)\Rightarrow(2)$ holds in case $A$ is an EP matrix.}
\end{rem}


\begin{prop}  \label{a-b-core}
Let $a,b \in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$. Then $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$ if and only if
$a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b=b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$,
$ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$,
$ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a=a.$
\end{prop}
\begin{proof}
Suppose $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$, then
     $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b=b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$ and
     $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
by Theorem \ref{core-minus-regular}.
Hence
$ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a=ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a=aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a=a.$
Conversely, suppose $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b=b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$ and
$ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$,
$ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a=a$, then
       $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a
       =a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a
       =a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b
       =a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$ and
        $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
       =ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
       =ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
       =ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}.$
\end{proof}

In \cite[Theorem 2.5]{MRT} Malik et al. investigated the reverse order law for two core invertible complex matrices
under the matrix core partial order. We extend this result as follows.


\begin{thm} \label{Reverse-order1}
Let $a,~b \in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ with $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$. Then \\
$(1)$ $(ab)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
      = b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
      = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = (ba)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$;\\
$(2)$ $ab\in R^\mathrm{EP}$ whenever $a\in R^\mathrm{EP}$.
\end{thm}
\begin{proof}
(1) In view of Theorem \ref{core-minus-regular},
    we have $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b=b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$.
    Simultaneously, we have
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    by Lemma \ref{five-equations-yy}.
    Thus,
      $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
    Note that $a^2 = ba$ by Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}(2).
    So we have
      $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $(a^2)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    = $(ba)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

    Now, let $x = b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
    Then \vskip 2mm

    $abx$ = $abb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
          = $aba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
          = $aaa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
          = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
          = $(aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^{*}$
          = $(abx)^{*}$,

    $abxab$ = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab$
            = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab$
            = $ab$,

    $xabx$ = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
           = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
           = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
           = $x$,

    $x(ab)^2$ = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}abab$
              = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^3b$
              = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{2}b$
              = $ab$, and

    $abx^2$ = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
            = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
            = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
            = $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
            = $x$.

    \vskip 2mm
    \noindent This shows $(ab)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
    according to Lemma \ref{five-equations-yy}.

(2) Suppose $a\in R^\mathrm{EP}$, then
    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = a^\dag = a^\#$ by Lemma \ref{five-equations-yy}.
    Hence $(a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a)^*$ = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$ = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
    To see that $ab\in R^\mathrm{EP}$,
    it suffices to verify
    $(ab)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}(ab)$ = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$
                                              = $(ab)(ab)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
    Indeed,
    \begin{eqnarray*}
          (ab)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}(ab)
    & = & a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab
      =   a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b
      =   a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a \\
    & = & aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
      =   aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
      =   aaa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}
      =   aba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} \\
    & = & (ab)(ab)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}.
    \end{eqnarray*}
    This completes the proof.
\end{proof}


\section{ Relationships between the core partial order and other partial orders }

In this section, we consider the relationships between core partial order and other partial orders in a $*$-ring $R$.

Recall from \cite{BM, D, LPT} that the left star partial order $\ast \!\!\leq$,
right star partial order $\leq\!\!\ast$ and star partial order $\overset{\ast}\leq$ in $R$
are defined as follows:
\begin{eqnarray*}
a \ \ast \!\!\leq    b & \Leftrightarrow & a^{\ast}a = a^{\ast}b \ \mathrm{and} \ aR\subseteq bR;     \\
a \leq \!\!\ast \    b & \Leftrightarrow & aa^{\ast} = ba^{\ast} \ \mathrm{and} \ Ra \subseteq Rb;    \\
a \overset{\ast}\leq b & \Leftrightarrow & a^{\ast}a = a^{\ast}b \ \mathrm{and} \ aa^{\ast} = ba^{\ast}.
\end{eqnarray*}
Given $a\in R^\#$ and $b\in R$,
according to \cite{M, MBM}, the sharp partial order $\overset{\#}\leq$ and the right sharp parital order $\leq_{\#}$
are defined as follows:
\begin{eqnarray*}
a \overset{\#}\leq b & \Leftrightarrow & a^\#a = a^\#b \ \mathrm{and} \ aa^\# = ba^\#; \\
a \leq_{\#} b      & \Leftrightarrow   & aa^\# = ba^\# \ \mathrm{and} \ Ra\subseteq Rb.
\end{eqnarray*}
The following lemma was proved for complex matrixes by Malik \cite[Theorem 2.5]{M2}
and for elements in Rickart $*$-rings by Raki\'{c} \cite[Theorem 4.8]{R}.
Note that it is valid for the general case here.

\begin{lem} \emph{\cite{M2, R}} \label{core-star-sharp}
Let $a\in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ and $b\in R$. Then $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$ if and only if
$a$ $\ast\!\!\leq b$ and $a\leq_{\#} b$.
\end{lem}

In \cite[Theorem 4.10]{RD}, Raki\'{c} and Djordjevi\'{c} gave the relationship between the core partial order and the minus partial order
for $a, b\in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
For instance, it is proved that $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$ if and only if $a\overset{-}\leq b$ and
$b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
By Lemma \ref{core-star-sharp}, the core partial order implies the left star partial order
and the right sharp partial order.
Motivated by \cite[Theorem 4.10]{RD}, we have the following theorem.


\begin{thm} \label{core-and-other}
Let $a,~b \in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$. Then the following are equivalent:\\
$(1)$ $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$;\\
$(2)$ $a$ $\ast\!\!\leq b$  and $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b=a$;\\
$(3)$ $a$ $\ast \!\!\leq b$ and $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$;\\
$(4)$ $a$ $\ast \!\!\leq b$ and $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$;\\
$(5)$ $a\leq_{\#} b$ and $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b=a$;\\
$(6)$ $a\leq_{\#} b$ and $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
\end{thm}
\begin{proof}
(1)$\Rightarrow$(2)-(6) is obvious by Theorem \ref{core-pr1}, Proposition \ref{a-b-core} and Lemma \ref{core-star-sharp}.

For (2)$\Rightarrow$(1), (3)$\Rightarrow$(1) and (4)$\Rightarrow$(1),
we need only to verify $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
by virtue of Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}.

(2)$\Rightarrow$(1) Since $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b = a$ by hypothesis and
                    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$ by Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}(1),
                    it follows that
                    $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ = $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                                                        = $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                                                        = $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

(3)$\Rightarrow$(1) Since $a$ $\ast\!\!\leq b$ we have $a = bc$ for some $c\in R$.
                    Hence $a = bc = bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bc = bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$.
                    Consequently,
                    $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ = $bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                                                        = $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    because $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

(4)$\Rightarrow$(1) From $b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    we get
                      $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    = $ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    = $a(b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
                    Note that $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$
                    by Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}(1).
                    In addition, it follows that $a = bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$ as we have seen in (3)$\Rightarrow$(1).
                    Whence
                      $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    = $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    = $ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    = $(bb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a)b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    = $b(b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})$
                    = $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

For (5)$\Rightarrow$(1) and (6)$\Rightarrow$(1),
we need only to verify $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
according to Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}.

(5)$\Rightarrow$(1) In view of Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}(2), we have
                    $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
                    Now, $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b = a$
                    implies
                      $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$
                    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
                    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
                    = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$.

(6)$\Rightarrow$(1) Since $a\leq_{\#} b$ we have $Ra\subseteq Rb$,
                    which implies $a$ = $cb$ for some $c\in R$
                    and hence $a$ = $cbb^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$ = $ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$.
                    Therefore,
                    $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$ = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}(ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b)$
                                                        = $(a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})b$
                                                        = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
                    as $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}=a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
\end{proof}


\begin{rem}\label{slip2}
\emph{Let $a\in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ and $b\in R^\mathrm{EP}$.
In \cite[Theorem $2.9$]{M2}, it is claimed that $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$
if and only if $a\leq\!\!\ast$ $b$ and
$b^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
in the complex matrix case. But it is not true.
In fact, let
$A=\left(\begin{matrix}
              1 & 1 \\
              0 & 0
       \end{matrix}
       \right),
B=\left(\begin{matrix}
              1 & 1 \\
              0 & 1
       \end{matrix}
       \right)\in \mathrm{M}_{2}(\mathbb{C})$\normalsize,
then $A$ is core invertible, $B$ is an EP matrix and the condition $A\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq B$ is satisfied,
but $AA^{\ast}\neq BA^{\ast}.$}
\end{rem}

The equivalence of $(2)$-$(4)$ in the following proposition for the complex matrices
has been proved by Malik et al. in \cite[Lemma 19]{MRT}.

\begin{prop} \label{k-core}
If $a\in R^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}, ~b\in R$ with $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$,
then the following conditions are equivalent:\\
$(1)$ $a\overset{\#}\leq b$;\\
$(2)$ $ab=ba$;\\
$(3)$ $a^{2}\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b^{2}$;\\
$(4)$ $a^{k}\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b^{k}$ for any $k\geq 2$.
\end{prop}
\begin{proof}
(1)$\Rightarrow$(2) Since $a\overset{\#}\leq b$ we have
                    $a^\#a = a^\#b$ and $aa^\# = ba^\#$.
                    Hence $ab$ = $a^2a^\#b$ = $a^2a^\#a$ = $aa^\#a^2$ = $ba^\#a^2$ = $ba$.

(2)$\Rightarrow$(4) Note that $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$ implies $ba = a^2$ by Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}.
                    If $ab = ba$ then it is easy to see that $ab^{k-1} = b^{k-1}a = a^k$ for any $k\geq 2$.
                    Since $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$
                    we have $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$ = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a$,
                    which guarantees
                    \begin{eqnarray*}
                          (a^{k})^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^{k}
                    & = & (a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^{k}b^{k}
                      =   (a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^{k-1}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}bb^{k-1}
                      =   (a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^{k-1}a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}ab^{k-1} \\
                    & = & (a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^{k}ab^{k-1}
                      =   (a^{k})^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^{k}.
                    \end{eqnarray*}
                    Similarly, one has $b^{k}(a^{k})^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}} = a^{k}(a^{k})^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.

(4)$\Rightarrow$(3) is clear.

(3)$\Rightarrow$(1) By $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$ and Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}(2),
                    it follows that $aa^{\#} = ba^{\#}$.
                    On the other hand,
                    we have $a^{\#}$ = $(a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^2a$
                    by \cite[Theorem 2.19(ii)]{RDD}.
                    Hence
                    $a^{\#}a$ = $(a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^2a^2$
                              = $(a^2)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a^2$
                              = $(a^2)^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b^2$
                              = $(a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}})^2b^2$
                              = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}(a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b)b$
                              = $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}(a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a)b$
                              = $a^{\#}b$.
                    Therefore, $a\overset{\#}\leq b$.
\end{proof}

Let $A, B\in \mathrm{M}_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ with $A$ an EP matrix.
Using the Hartwig--Spindelb\"{o}ck decomposition, Baksalary and Trenker \cite[Theorem 7]{BT} proved that
$A\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq B$ if and only if $A\overset{\ast}\leq B$.
Similarly, Mailk \cite[Theorem 3.3]{M2} proved that
$A\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq B$
if and only if $A\overset{\#}\leq B$.
We extend these results from $\mathrm{M}_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ to an arbitrary $*$-ring.

\begin{thm}  \label{EP-core-other}
Let $a\in R^\mathrm{EP}$ and $b\in R$, then the following are equivalent:\\
$(1)$ $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$;\\
$(2)$ $a\overset{\#}\leq b$;\\
$(3)$ $a\overset{\ast}\leq b$.
\end{thm}
\begin{proof}
(1)$\Rightarrow$(2) Suppose $a\overset{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}\leq b$
                    then $aa^\#$ = $ba^\#$ and $a^{*}a = a^{*}b$ by Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}.
                    Since $a\in R^\mathrm{EP}$ we have $a^\#$ = $a^\dag$ and hence
                    $a^\#a$ = $a^\dag a$ = $a^\dag aa^\dag a$ = $a^\dag (aa^\dag)^* a$
                            = $a^\dag (a^\dag)^*a^*a$ = $a^\dag (a^\dag)^*a^*b$
                            = $a^\dag (aa^\dag)^* b$ = $a^\dag aa^\dag b$
                            = $a^\dag b$ = $a^\#b$.
                    This shows $a\overset{\#}\leq b$.

(2)$\Rightarrow$(3) Since $a\overset{\#}\leq b$ and $a\in R^\mathrm{EP}$,
                    it follows that
                    $a^{\dagger}a$ = $a^\#a$ = $a^\#b$ = $a^{\dagger}b$.
                    Whence
                    $a^*a$ = $a^*aa^\dag a$ = $a^*aa^\dag b$ = $a^*(aa^\dag)^* b$ = $(aa^\dag a)^* b$ = $a^*b$.
                    Similarly, one can get $aa^{\ast} = ba^{\ast}$.
                    Thus, $a\overset{\ast}\leq b$ holds.

(3)$\Rightarrow$(1) Suppose $a\overset{\ast}\leq b$, i.e., $a^{\ast}a$ = $a^{\ast}b$ and $aa^{\ast} = ba^{\ast}$.
                    Then $a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}a = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}b$
                    by Lemma \ref{lemma-partial2}(1).
                    On the other hand,
                    by \cite[Theorem 3.1]{RDD} we get $a^\dag = a^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$
                    since $a\in R^\mathrm{EP}$.
                    Consequently,
                    $aa^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$ = $aa^\dag$
                                                        = $aa^\dag aa^\dag$
                                                        = $a(a^\dag a)^*a^\dag$
                                                        = $aa^*(a^\dag)^*a^\dag$
                                                        = $ba^*(a^\dag)^*a^\dag$
                                                        = $b(a^\dag a)^*a^\dag$
                                                        = $ba^\dag aa^\dag$
                                                        = $ba^\dag$
                                                        = $ba^{\tiny{\textcircled{\tiny\#}}}$.
                    Therefore (1) follows.
\end{proof}
